reviewText:
Bus Simulator 16 was developed by still alive studios and published by Astragon. The game released on the 2nd March 2016 for a price of £18.99.

In Bus Simulator 16, you are in charge of a bus company and must also drive around the bus collecting and dropping off people on various routes. During my hour of playing this game I had many ups and downs but the eventual ending was me stuck outside my bus and also stuck outside the depot with no way back.

Positives:
+ Good attempt at an entry level bus simulator – The game was designed to be a really good bus simulator but unfortunately falls quite short of that bar. The game feels more entry level but a good attempt at it.
+  Steam Workshop – With steam workshop there will be mods to improve the game and adding own designs and busses.
+ Tutorial – The tutorial is pretty good and I’m glad I did it. The amount of options and choices to the game is overbearing at times but I feel after an hour more confident  to try and drive a bus around.
+ Multiplayer – This is a great add to the game, you can play online and manage routes together too, the only problem for me is that I lack friends with the game 
+ Cops/Police – When I was idle at the station trying to figure out buttons and such a Police car went flying past me with the lights on. I found this so cool – however it may just be normal for most people.

Negatives:
- Floaty handling – The handling is not too good on this game and most the time I end up crashing and bashing when taking corners because the handling is too light.
- Overwhelmed – There are just so many options, buttons, choices in which you must do and then to add to the top of all that the doors get jammed and the customers expect you to give them change from money which you can’t really make out.
- Voice acting – If you can make it through the game without laughing at the terrible voice acting I commend you. I laughed quite often due to this fact.
- Long loading times – It may just be my PC but I experienced agonising load times and very bad FPS.
- Price – I feel the price should be halfed for the product because although you get a lot of content the quality is subpar.

Unfortunately I felt this game had a lot of potential but the execution was pretty bad. I was hoping to finally get an Omni 2 experience on Steam but unfortunately this falls well below expectations and to me feels more of an entry product. I could only recommend this game to people with low expectations or standards (huehue). I played this game only for an hour but  I was left out in Sunny Springs in the rain, trapped from my bus and depot. Although I slate the game I enjoyed it for what it was but can’t possibly recommend the game at the current price point. I’m just glad the game never crashed on me because that would’ve been the icing on the cake.

Score: Wait for a sale

It's not every time I review a game, but I thought the need to review this game was high! Bus Simulator 16 is set in the town of Sunny Springs. Not only are you a bus driver, but you have to deal with a variety of events that happen around you!

Driving the Bus The driving and stability of the bus is relatively easy. I'm currently using a Logitech G27 and I'm able to turn the steering wheel with no problem. However, I feel it can be quite stiff sometimes, but I'm sure this will be improved.

The Passengers The passengers are amazing. You get a variety of different talks whilst driving your bus, from calling in sick to work, talking to fellow passengers etc. Other than when I give passengers their ticket, they say 'Thank you dear'. There are also other events including asking a passenger to move so you can close the doors, helping a wheelchair user onto the bus where you may need to get out of your seat and operate it manually or press a button at the cab, turning the air con/heating up or down to the passengers' wish or even dealing with drunk passengers. Pedestrians also relatively behave probably, I do get the occasional event where a passenger walks out in front of me at a crossing and your current drive would end immediately.
There are also other events including fixing a jammed door, where you need to get out of your seat and manually close the door.

Graphics and Textures The graphics overall are pretty good. I've been hearing reports about the textures glitching out and turning to grey, however I have not been getting this problem. A feature I do like is when it's raining and the trees blow around. Unfortunately, when it is raining, you don't get any rain effects on the windscreen which was quite a disappointment. There are wipers, but there is no point in really using these.

The AI Vehicles  The AI's behaviour in-game is very good, they will react to your indicators very well, like when you are pulling out of a bus stop, the car behind you will stop and let you out. There does seem to be a glitch where if you are sat in the cockpit, you won't be able to see the AI's lights (indicators, brake lights) but you will be able to see them from outside of the bus. This might explain to some people why they have been crashing into the back of AI cars, which I have done a couple of times.  AI will also behave probably when at traffic lights or junctions, so the developers have done a good job on coding the AI vehicles!

The FPS I get in-game The FPS I get in-game is relatively good to keep it stable. I get around 40-50FPS overall when driving around or walking about in my office/garage. I have been looking at the reviews where some people have put a thumbs down because of the poor FPS they get in-game. I seem to be one of the lucky ones where I don't get any FPS problems and can play the game with no problem. However, I'm sure for those who are getting problems that there will be a patch relatively soon.

Overall Conclusion Overall, I believe Bus Simulator 16 is a great simulator and is much better than the previous bus simulator I had, which was OMSI 2, which had no end of glitches, crashes and bad in-game optimization etc. It's not every day you get a good Bus Simulator like this, probably one of the best to date. There may be a few glitches and bugs there and there, but let's be grateful that we have a good Bus Simulator!

IT'S AN OMSI 2 FOR NOOBS (and that's a good thing)

I was always interested in the various bus simulators, but always found the learning curve to be too steep. Games like OMSI 2 while great, are too insanely detailed for their own good, putting off someone like myself from really giving it a chance.

ETS2/ATS on the otherhand proved to me that you can make a accessible simulator while keeping it just deep enough to please the hardcore. I simply wanted a bus simulator that followed the ETS2 mold and Bus Simulator 2016 is a great first step at that.

PROS:
- Easy to pick up and play. It comes with a nice tutorial for first timers.
- The city feels alive and lived in. There are a variety of passengers (including drunk and wheel chair bound patrons).
- The added business simulation element gives you incentive to continue and improve your driving skills as it directly effects your bottom line.
- Ability to easily create and drive routes. A simple 5 stop route to a monster 50 stop route is possible.
- You can buy and customize your buses with decals, earn extra money by placing ads, and hire drivers to drive them.
- Relatively stable performance. Did not crash once (unlike a certain other game).
- Supports the Thrustmaster TX 458 Italia (by customizing the controls).

CONS:
- No TrackIR support (the mouse is used)
- Needs more optimization
- No real multiplayer to speak of (driving with friends).
- The AI traffic lacks other buses. It would be nice to see your competitors as well as your own buses running the same streets as it currently feels like you are the only bus driver in town.
- No penalty for arriving too early for your next stop. I've finished my route as early as 8 minutes without penalty. **Perhaps this is something that is unlocked later in game?

reviewText:
This is a very engaging and interesting game. You do more than just drive a bus - you also have to manage your own bus company, organise routes, deal with a variety of interesting situations (bus malfunctions, demanding passengers etc.), buy new buses, hire new drivers and so on. You get missions that help you unlock new features. You're never short of something to do.

Bus Simulator 16 is made by the same people who developed Bus Simulator 2012, albeit with a different partner this time. I gave Bus Simulator 2012 a negative review, but I am happy to say that Bus Simulator 16 is a vast improvement - with one exception. Bus Simulator 2012 had awful frame rates, and unfortunately, so does Bus Simulator 2016 at present. I played on medium graphic settings with a pretty powerful computer, but found the gameplay very laggy and choppy, although just bearable. But I can play games like Euro Truck Simulator 2 or Train Simulator 2016 on high settings and have no FPS issues. So this is an area that needs work. And apparently, the developers are working on it, so hopefully performance will be much better soon.

Some areas where Bus Simulator 2016 has improved on BS 2012 include keyboard steering (much, MUCH better, more like Euro Truck or American Truck Simulator steering now), AI traffic (much more sensible, accidents are usually due to your bad driving rather than their stupidity) and user-friendliness of the bus interior (no more password to enter, selling tickets is now much more efficiently handled). And of course, it introduces new things that were never seen in BS 2012, like the whole company management deal, missions and so on.

Other than the need for performance optimisation, I have few complaints about this game. It is definitely the best bus simulator since OMSI 2, and has real potential to give the latter a serious run for its money. I am more than happy to recommend it.

reviewText:
Bus Simulator 16 played using a Driving Force GT steeringwheel.

BS16 is a surprise for me. I have little affinity with public transport if it isn't screaming along on a set of rails pulling a metric crapton of cargo-carriages. Another consideration is that I didn't think that coming to a stop at every lamppost would be fun.

But BS16 takes the concept of driving something bulky through crowded streets and makes a potentially aggrivating activity a fun and enjoyable thing to do. The driving takes place in a colorful, full featured city that's brought alive by lots of traffic and pedastrians on the sidewalks. In my hours played already, I have never been in the 'last person on earth doing a public service job' situation many simulators tend to put the player in.

The busses come in several flavors and are relatively easy to drive. There's little difference between them as they all have to same start up routine, the same transmission times, the same speeds, the same turn-radius and the same stupid ability to start driving backwards when you apply the brakes. (Errata: A setting in the options vaguely called 'drive aids' corrects that.)

As a busdriver, you transport people along a busline that's initially set, but after a short while, you can erase that baby's first busline and construct your own lines, which you can also share online for other people to drive. When other people drive your shared line, you get paid.
You sell tickets to people and have to give them correct change if they don't pay with ready money. Sadly, the amount of money they use to pay is not varied enough so that after a few stops you start giving people their change with your eyes closed. So, and idea that was initially fun, becomes a tedious chore due to how limited they made it.
Passengers are interactive. A disabled person in wheelchair might need your help embarking or disembarking, an absent minded person might need to be made aware that you can't close the doors if he doesn't move further into the bus. The passengers have silly conversations that regularly make me laugh. One such an exchange really had me in stiches as a young woman rung up her mother on her cellphone to loudly exclaim that she was finally pregnant followed by 'No, I'm not at home, I'm in a bus!'.

At first, I struggled with operating my bus. I kept clipping the curb, stepped on the brakes too heavy, stepped on the brakes too lightly, steered too little or steered too much and generally was allover the place. If the game wasn't so colorful, or if the game wasn't so alive with everything that's going on, I wouldn't have stuck with it as I did. After a while, it clicked and I was doing the rounds as if I had never done anything but drive busses all of my life. As I gained skill, my enjoyment of the game grew accordingly.

As the manager of a bussing company, you can decorate your busses, get advertizement contracts, create buslines, hire and fire drivers and amass mountains of money. You advance your company's reach and reputation at a steady pace and you get a good feel of accomplishment out of it. Within the first few hours of play you're admiring your budding fleet of busses, see the map get filled by your buslines and smile as the game shows you a pop-up that someone has driven one of your shared lines which made a nice amount of cash.

The traffic AI needs a good look-over however. It's downright more stupid than a bag of hammers in a glass-factory. When they do what they're supposed to do, it's fine and it makes the city-driving all the more realistic. But they more often do the stupid and annoy you by making sure that your bottomline is wrecked by financial setbacks you can't avoid. Pedastrians aren't much better, prone to start crossing the road when you're manouvring to rounda corner. That results in a 'big accident' that immedeately ends your run. When that happens near the end of a 30minute drive, there's little reason to smile. I don't mind failing because I made a mistake. I do mind failing because the AI is as stupid as the developer tasked with developing with the AI.

Using a steeringwheel with forcefeedback and a 900degree turn is in my opinion a must. It really adds that extra like adding wheelturn resistance, which simulates that awesome 'I'm steering a huge and bulky vehicle' experience. The 900degrees wheelturn also removes the twitch-steering you get with the keyboard or a controller; making the turning more ponderous. The difference is really between night and day and heightens the immersion greatly.

If the entire package wasn't so colorful, if the streets were scarcely populated, if the management layer would've been treadbare, if the passengers were badly animated cardboard cut outs, then the things like the busses all handling the same and the AI being terminally stupid would make BS16 just another 'german simulator with nothing to live for'.
As it stands however, BS16 is saved by the attention to detail and many other things that really makes me feel that I'm a busdriver doing the rounds in a believable, albeit none existant, european city.

Thumbs up then. If the developers keep working on this title and keep bettering it, then this game could become a benchmark for city-driving simulators. It's halfway to greatness already and I wholeheartedly recommend you this title.

As promised, here is my review of the bus simulator  16. I played for nearly 8h and streamed it the whole time.

While this is true the game is not optimized at all and this could make it impossible to play for some people, this game is far from the 45-50% rating it received on release. I'm glad it's back to 60% as I'm writing this review and I believe it could deserve to be a little higher like 70-75% because the game itself isn't bad. The devs just have a very hard time to optimize it and they are working on it very hard. I cross my fingers they release a fix quickly. But don't be fooled by those bad reviews. Almost none of those rate the game for what it is, they are just bad reviews of angry players not able to launch the game and not patient enough to give the devs a chance to release a fix.

This game is not OMSI 2! If you seek for an incrediblely detailed bus simulator, don't buy. This game is more arcadish. If I had to compare it to other games, I would say it's like if OMSI 2 and Cities in Motion had a baby together. You have the management part of Cities in Motion (you create bus routes, assign drivers and busses to them, make sure they are giving positive income, etc). And with that you have the driving part of OMSI 2 (you drive buses, interact with passengers, deal with traffic, etc). You can interact with buttons in cockpit view. I was surprised there was so much to interact with in fact. So while it's not OMSI 2, it's still not a lazy game where you only accelerate/decelerate/left/right and nothing else. The driving is not the most realistic one but still very fun and it works very well with G27. Just a bit hard to set it up on first time but pretty fine after some gaming time.

The multiplayer is a nice add considering lot of driving games never have one. Sadly, it's not a real multi. As you cannot see your drivers (AI) on the road, well you cannot see other players aswell in multi. It's more like if other players were replacing the AI so they are supposedly better drivers than AI but the mechanism behind is exactly the same. Very disappointed by this but I salute the effort. SCS (Euro and American Truck Simulator dev) never bothered trying to add a multi while players are hardly requesting it. StillAlive has work to do to catch on SCS but at least they tried. Let's give them a chance to improve. SCS didn't become a great truck sim developer in one day after all. ;)

Only down side of the game are the graphics. They are not stunning at all and the game is more laggy than GTA V (I run it almost at ultra while I can barely run the bus sim at  medium with a poor 20FPS). Optimization is what hurts this game right now. As I said, I cross fingers the devs fix that soon. It's really annoying to have 30-45 second loading screen on launch and I'm lucky, some players must wait 4-5 minutes!

So yes, if you are not patient to wait for a fix, don't buy or request a refund. But please, this game doesn't deserve so much bad reviews just because those devs are not experienced enough and have a little struggle optimizing their game. From a huge studio, I would have not forgiven such a mess with optimization, but for StillAlive, I'm ready to give them some time. I hope they will make good use of it.

reviewText:
Plain and simple, this is the bus driving game I've been waiting for. What gets me excited about playing this game are the little things that do a lot to the immersion: Passengers running late, waiving at you in hopes you won't take off without them; traffic that doesn't constantly crash into you or each other but yield when you indicate that you are about to set off; jammed doors or passengers blocking doors from closing; handicapped passengers in need of a ramp; events like dynamic construction sites or an ambulance with wailing sirens, etc..

Further, Bus Simulator 16 gives you incentives to drive safely as you gain more reputation with your passengers when you do not drive like a maniac. You can if you want to, but it will hurt the rate of your progression (and your economy):

Like Euro Truck Simulator 2, Bus Simulator 16 additionally has a management simulation mechanic which lets you buy new busses, hire drivers to generate additional revenue, customize your vehicles and even create all the routes on your own. These things (including new districts) are unlocked step by step as your reputation grows.

If you have played other public transportation simulators before then you quickly learn the controls. The tutorial is also a good addition in explaining all the important elements. Handling and getting the bus to move is easier in Bus Simulator 16 than for example OMSI 2. Therefore, hardcore OMSI fans might get a little dissatisfied as mastering your vehicle is way simpler.

The five available districs are rich in variety and the city is actually bigger than it seems when looking at the map. Unfortunately, the tool for creating routes does not give you any degree of freedom when it comes to choosing which road you want to use, resulting in odd and annoying routing in some cases.
Further, and despite Bus Simulator 16 being neatly polished for a simulation game, it is quite heavy on performance. So if you do not have a very 'potent' computer you might get really poor framerates.

Nonetheless, this game got me motivated and hooked right from the start. I hope for additional features for the route creation tool and performance improvements but apart from that I consider my 25 bucks well spent.

At this moment i been playing the game for 3 hours. The first impressions are nice. You take over the bus company from a old man who is gonna retire. Up to you to build out the company and keep it healthy while you drive around in busses yourself as well.

I really like how they put in little details with the passengers. In other bus simulators they are rather static and only react to certain things when you mess up. In Bus Simulator 16 your passengers talk with others so you can hear the conversations at times, they play around with their phone, checking for messages or playing games on it. But not for the whole ride, its not a animation that keeps playing till they leave the bus.
Pedestrians also feel more alive, when they cross a street and a car is getting close they start to run.
Emergency vehicles now also make their way trough the traffic, passing by when someone is standing still. A huge improvement over the others where they tend to stay behind cars and waiting in line till its their turn. They also drive trough the red light so you have make sure you let them go first when you hear the sirens.
Another great thing are random events like maintenance to the road that makes you have to take a detour, problems with the bus you need to fix and you even get passengers in wheelchairs that you actually have to help with the ramp depending on what bus you are controlling. Don't forget this cause me and others already didn't notice them and drove off just to get the message i forgot a passenger.

There are also some minor things. If you are a die hard simmer then this game might be a bit to arcady for you. Unlike it's competition you don't need to remember a lot of buttons and manage all aspects of the bus to make sure the temperature and such is good enough.
This makes it easyer for beginners to get into or those who like driving a bus but find the competition to hard, but for those who are looking for the next big bus simulator this might be a disapointment.
There are also some optimization issues going on, when you read the negative reviews you will see a few of them. I personally haven't had the game crash on me once, nor having any bug showing up ingame. Though the game could use some optimzation, i first thought it was my pc but reading the negative reviews it is the game appearantly. Though i lower my range of view and that helped alot with the fps drops.
There are also long loading screens, however once it loaded the city it has loaded everything so when you unlocked the city you can drive around without any issues.

There is also a multiplayer aspect though that means you can get a friend drive routes for your company and earn money for your company. Sadly you can't see them driving around in the same world. I hope they will add this cause that would be great.

The good:

+ Create your own routes
+ Passengers feel more alive then before
+ Nice details in behavior from emergency vehicles, pedestrians and passengers
+ Random events

The minor:

- Perhaps to arcady for the die hard simmers
- Could use a bit more optimization (though it isn't to bad)
- No other players in your world when playing the multiplayer

reviewText:
Can't really recommend this game in its current state, it feels more like a pre-alpha than a finished game. If it was released as an Early Access title I'd be more inclined to give it the benefit of doubt.
It runs poorly on an i7 2600K@4.3Ghz + GTX970, it uses only 1 CPU thread (and even that only at 50 to 70%) and the GPU usage sits at 40~50%. With the lowest possible settings I'm only getting around 40 to 50fps at 1080p, but with those settings the viewdistance is so small that it looks like you're driving through fog. High settings net me around 27-33 fps and maxed out is completely unplayable due the low fps and stutter.

I can see this becoming a good game with a performance fix, gameplay changes and a lot of polish, but as it stands it's not worth €25 and it definitely shouldn't be a full release.

Update: I've tried the new update, there is a performance improvement, I went from ~30 fps on High to ~35 fps now, still abysmal performance (even worse if you factor in how the game looks). There's also noticeable stutter that becomes pretty annoying.
Update 2: Have tried the new performance improving patch, now the average for high settings is around 37 fps, which is still far from acceptable. Not to mention all of this should have been done before the game was released.
When I'm going to get 60fps on high settings I'm going to change my review, until then it's still not recommended.

Adding an image so you can see how the game looks on the lowest of settings: http://i.imgur.com/f9Eodlm.jpg
Only getting 50 fps with those kinds of settings (Update 2: after this update I'm getting about 60-70 fps on the lowest settings).

reviewText:
It's apparent that stillalive studios has made a wholeheartedly attempt at making a bus simulator.
The game lets you control everything from opening the garage door to printing tickets and giving change to you customers. The games UI feels fresh and modern and is pretty easily navigated. I like that you can make your own bus routes and assign drivers to drive them.

Unfortunately for me, the games falls flat in one of the most important mechanics, the driving part.
The handling feels very loose and the bus veers all over the place, and I'm playing on a controller with the sensitivity on its minimum setting. It doesn't feel like you are steering a 14-ton bus when it jerks at the smallest input on the joystick.

As mentioned by other players, the voice acting is not very good. At all. And before reaching my first hour of playtime i was already hearing the same chatter from the people in my bus as i was hearing in the beginning, it seems that they haven't recorded that many lines for people to say.

The game has a couple of pretty interesting mechanics though. The doors on the bus can jam and you will be forced to close them manually, emergency vehicles can rush up behind you with their sirens on wanting you to move over, there's dynamical construction sites and more stuff.

But ultimately, for me, the game has potential but i cannot recommend it in its current state. The steering is too off and the game has some obvious optimization issues. I'm considering refunding it and maybe coming back if it's patched.
